title: 104_s1122
content: The Act may be cited as the "Criminal Copyright Improvement Act of 1995" and addresses criminal infringement of copyrights. The "Criminal Copyright Improvement Act of 1995" defines financial gain as receiving anything of value, including other copyrighted works. It also outlines criminal infringement for purposes of commercial advantage or private financial gain, with penalties for reproducing or distributing copyrighted works worth $5,000 or more. The Criminal Copyright Improvement Act of 1995 increases penalties for criminal infringement of copyright, including reproduction or distribution, with amendments to sections 507(a) and 2319 of title 17 and title 18 of the United States Code. The Criminal Copyright Improvement Act of 1995 enhances penalties for copyright infringement, specifically reproduction or distribution, by amending sections 507(a) and 2319 of title 17 and title 18 of the United States Code. The Act increases the threshold for retail value from $2,500 to $5,000 and imposes a maximum penalty of 5 years imprisonment for offenses under section 506(a)(2) of title 17. The Criminal Copyright Improvement Act of 1995 increases penalties for copyright infringement, including reproduction or distribution of copyrighted works valued over $10,000. Offenders can face up to 1 year in prison or fines. Repeat offenses can lead to up to 10 years in prison. Victims can submit impact statements during the sentencing process. Victims can submit impact statements during the sentencing process, identifying the victim, extent of injury and loss, and economic impact of the offense. The Criminal Copyright Improvement Act of 1995 allows victims of copyright offenses to submit impact statements during sentencing, detailing the extent of injury, loss, and economic impact. Victims include producers, sellers, and holders of legitimate works affected by the offense. Amendments to Section 2320 of title 18 address trafficking in counterfeit goods or services. Amendments to title 18, United States Code allow victims of offenses to submit impact statements during sentencing, detailing injury, loss, and economic impact. Victims include producers, sellers, and holders of legitimate goods affected by the offense. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to ensure that sentencing guidelines for crimes against intellectual property are stringent enough to deter such crimes and reflect additional considerations. The Sentencing Commission must consider the retail value and quantity of infringed items when implementing guidelines for crimes against intellectual property.
